Sabrina and I early voted in Batavia!

This bill was one of the principal reasons Intel decided to locate its new chip plant in the US, outside of Columbus. Rob Portman voted for the bill, but not Brad!
I would have voted for the bill.

Thanks to a follower for another #BadBradVotes.
Brad Wenstrup voted against the America Competes Act which will boost domestic production of semiconductors and provide more funding for scientific research.
I came up with a week of #BadBradVotes with almost no effort. If you have a favorite #BadBradVotes send it to me at info@alan4congress.com

The 2nd District needs the investment this bill will make in our roads and bridges, our electric grid, our water and sewer systems, and yes (finally) in high speed reliable internet throughout the region. Voting no went squarely against our interests. I would have voted yes!

Day 7 of #BadBradVotes

Brad Wenstrup's vote against the Infrastructure Bill is probably the hardest for me to understand. The bill was going to pass whichever way he voted. It seems like he enjoyed sticking his thumb in the eyes of the voters of the 2nd District to vote no!

I would favor a more broadly based tax cut, one that put extra money in the hands of people who actually need it. These people will spend their extra money and this will accelerate the effect on the economy. This is called trickle up.

Corporations were supposed to invest the extra cash in their businesses, creating more jobs. Instead they initiated massive stock buybacks. Very few people in the 2nd District benefitted from this tax cut except for Brad's big money donors.

This tax cut was another attempt by Republicans to prove that trickle down, giving money to the "job creators",  would benefit the economy. The very rich either socked their extra cash away or spent it on luxury goods and services.

Day 6 of #BadBradVotes

Brad Wenstrup voted for the 2017 tax cut. How can voting for a tax cut be a bad vote? If the benefits of the tax cut are heavily targeted toward the richest of the rich and toward corporations, then voting for it would be a bad vote.

I favor making it easier to register and to vote. I also favor making elections fairer by getting rid of the vast amount of dark money in campaigns and eliminating gerrymandering. These 2 "features" of modern politics entrench incumbents in power.

According to the Brennan Center, more than 440 bills with provisions that restrict voting access have been introduced in 49 states in the 2021 legislative sessions. The John R. Lewis Act will make it easier to register and vote. Brad Wenstrup has consistently voted against it.

Day 5 of #BadBradVotes
In 2020 this country had higher turnout than usual in an election held in the middle of a pandemic. All fact-based analyses have shown that the the election was clean. Yet Republicans keep pushing a fraud narrative without proof.

Day 4 of #BadBradVotes
In December of 2021 Brad Wenstrup voted against renewing the expanded Child Tax Credit which benefited many people in Ohio's 2nd District. It was found to reduce childhood poverty by 30% and food insufficiency by 25%.
The extra money made it easier for families with children to make it through the month. Since the money tended to be spent locally, it also helped boost the local economy. Classic trickle-up.

The Ohio Supreme Court is scheduled to take up the blatantly unconstitutional map, but not until after the May 3 primary. That's why Congress is in this primary. It's possible that the lines might change between the primary and the general. https://t.co/Erx3kFPyle
https://t.co/qyo5czuG0Q

At a minimum we should pass the SAFE Act. This bill grants cannabis companies, in states where it's legal, access to the US banking system. This will cut down on the amount of cash these companies handle. Brad also voted against the SAFE Act!

I would have voted for it. We should treat marijuana like alcohol - legalize it, regulate it, tax it. We are spending too much money and ruining too many lives by treating marijuana like we do opioids!

Day 3 of #BadBradVotes
On April 1, the House passed the MORE Act which  removed marijuana from the controlled substances list, expunged previous convictions, and gave legal marijuana businesses access to the federal banking system. Brad Wenstrup voted against this bill.

This is not a perfect bill. It doesn't affect the cost of insulin; it limits copayments and deductibles. However, while we wait for a better bill, it offers relief to people who are struggling. We need to make health care more affordable in this country.

Day 2 of #BadBradVotes
On March 31 the House passed the Affordable Insulin Now Act. Brad Wenstrup voted no. This vote comes at a time when many people in our district have to ration their use of insulin because of the cost. A $35 monthly cap would certainly help them!
